title: Mortgage brokers win another break on commissions
text:
For example, if a home loan of $750,000 is granted including a potential $250,000 drawdown facility, the commission will initially be paid on $500,000.

If the potential extra $250,000 is "drawn down" within 12 months – instead of three months – the broker will earn an additional commission.

The situation typically applies when a borrower requests more funds than required for the purchase in order to fund renovations.

Australian Finance Group general manager Mark Hewitt welcomed the Treasurer's announcement on commissions for loan drawdowns.

"Thanks to Mr Frydenberg and the government for consulting with the industry and reaching this sensible outcome," he said.

"It will ensure brokers continue to be fairly remunerated for their hard work in finding the right solutions for their customers."

But consumer advocates expressed concern.

CHOICE policy and campaigns adviser Patrick Veyret said the government's announcement "yet again exposes the mortgage broking lobby’s single-minded concern: the continuation of conflicted commissions at the expense of consumer best interests”.

Advertisement

“Mortgage broking lobbyists have again pressured the government to water down strong protections that ensure brokers don’t recommend more expensive mortgages than people need.

“A 90-day drawdown is an important safeguard to prevent the broking industry from recommending larger mortgages than people need in order to receive a higher upfront commission.”

Best interest duty

The government is introducing a "best interest duty" for mortgage brokers and is banning campaign and volume-based commissions.

Two months before the May election, the government backflipped on a key recommendation of the banking royal commission to ban trail commissions for mortgage brokers from 2020.

Instead, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and the Council on Federal Financial Relations will hold a review into whether trail commissions should be kept from 2020 onwards.

The Coalition earlier rejected Commissioner Kenneth Hayne's recommendation that the borrower, not the lender, pay the upfront fee.

Mortgage brokers have been arguably the most effective business lobby group in response to the Hayne royal commission, winning a series of key backdowns from the government on the inquiry's recommendations.

Advertisement

Former Productivity Commission chairman Peter Harris had urged the government earlier this month to boost home loan competition by creating a tough “best interest duty” for mortgage brokers so that loyal customers do not get ripped off.

A strong best interest duty would counteract the commission incentive, he said.

“Brokers are paid these trailing commissions and if someone is refinancing they go first to the existing loan provider, but there could be a better deal out there,” he said.

“The best interest duty will counteract the incentive created by the trailing commission, which we are yet to see the government eliminate.”
description: The Morrison government has allowed them more time to earn commissions for borrowers "drawing down" extra debt on a mortgage facility.
